title: Socialist defeats far-right candidate in Portugal's presidential runoff, exit polls show
description: LISBON, Feb 8 () - Moderate Socialist Antonio Jose Seguro appeared to be ‚Äãheaded for a landslide victory in ‚ÄåPortugal's presidential runoff on Sunday, with two exit polls ‚Äåputting him in the 67%-73% r...
fullText:
LISBON, Feb 8 (Reuters) - Moderate Socialist Antonio Jose Seguro appeared to be ‚Äãheaded for a landslide victory in ‚ÄåPortugal's presidential runoff on Sunday, with two exit polls ‚Äåputting him in the 67%-73% range, well ahead of his far-right, anti-establishment rival Andre Ventura.

The exit polls conducted for television ‚Å†channels RTP, SIC ‚Äåand TVI/CNN placed Ventura at 27%-33%, still a better result than ‚Äçthe 22.8% his anti-immigration Chega party achieved in last year's general election.

Last year, Chega became ‚Äãthe second-largest parliamentary force, overtaking the ‚ÄåSocialists and landing behind the centre-right ruling alliance, which garnered 31.2%.

Despite his loss on Sunday, 43-year-old Ventura, a charismatic former TV sports commentator, can now boast increased ‚Å†support, reflecting the growing ‚Äãinfluence of the far ‚Äãright in Portugal and much of Europe.

The presidency is a largely ceremonial ‚Äçrole in ‚Å†Portugal but wields some key powers, including in some circumstances to dissolve parliament, ‚Å†to call a snap parliamentary election, and to ‚Äåveto legislation.

title: The state accused a Caldwell company of deceiving customers. Then this happened
description: The company agreed to change its advertising practices after the Attorney General‚Äôs office sued.
fullText:
A Caldwell company agreed to change its advertising after Idaho Attorney General Ra√∫l Labrador‚Äôs office accused the business of misleading customers.

Labrador‚Äôs office sued Right Now Heating, Cooling & Plumbing, alleging it was running deceptive direct-mail advertisements that claimed customers could obtain a furnace or air conditioning unit for a discounted price. Right Now denied the allegations.

‚ÄúYou can get rid of your old furnace and replace with a brand new, top of the line furnace for $1,200,‚Äù one of the advertisements said.

The Attorney General‚Äôs Office alleges that the claim and others made by the company were not true.

The lawsuit said that to get a new furnace, the customer would have to pay the installation cost for the furnace and a new air conditioning unit, and Right Now‚Äôs ad ‚Äúdoes not disclose clearly and conspicuously the cost of the furnace or provide the complete cost to purchase and install both units.‚Äù

Labrador‚Äôs office said customers have complained that the company failed to provide them with an itemized contract identifying the equipment and services they agreed to buy, and that they were provided a document titled ‚Äúestimate‚Äù that the company contended was a sales contract.

Labrador‚Äôs office said the company‚Äôs ‚Äúestimate‚Äù had a tendency to mislead or confuse reasonable customers. It accused Right Now of a pattern of unfair competition and deceptive acts that violate the Idaho Consumer Protection Act and the Idaho Rules of Consumer Protection.

The Attorney General‚Äôs Office and Right Now agreed to an assurance of voluntary compliance in which the company agreed to change its advertising to clearly disclose the total cost it charges customers to purchase and install its HVAC products. For instance, if the company advertises that a customer can purchase an air conditioner for $1,475 installed, it must sell the air conditioner for that price.

The agreement, in which Right Now does not admit liability, requires the company to keep all records related to customer complaints it receives for two years after the date it takes effect.

‚ÄúRight Now‚Äôs stipulations to the terms of this assurance do not constitute admissions by it to any facts or violations of any state or federal law, rule or regulation,‚Äù the agreement says. ‚ÄúRight Now enters into this assurance for the purpose of resolving the Attorney General‚Äôs concerns ... ‚Äú

The company agreed to pay the Attorney General‚Äôs office $6,500 for fees and costs it incurred in pursing the lawsuit.

Canyon County District Judge Randall Grove approved the agreement on Dec. 22.

title: Green Day Just Called Out Trump After the President Refused to Attend the Super Bowl & Called Them a ‚ÄòTerrible Choice‚Äô
description: Likely thing for them to do!
fullText:
Green Day has never been part of the MAGA agenda. The California rock band has called out Donald Trump and his administration in many of their music performances, and it doesn‚Äôt look like they‚Äôre stopping any time soon.

In recent years, the band‚Äîconsisting of members Billie Joe Armstrong, Mike Dirnt, and Tr√© Cool‚Äîhas replaced the lyrics of their iconic hit ‚ÄúAmerican Idiot.‚Äù The song, written in 2004, initially included the lyrics¬†‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a part of a redneck agenda.‚Äù Now, when performing the song live, Armstrong sings, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not part of the MAGA agenda.‚Äù The song itself, and the titular album it was written for, was a direct criticism of George W. Bush‚Äôs administration and the Iraq war.

Trump Finally Addresses Savannah Guthrie's Mom's Abduction Years After She Called His Behavior 'Crazy' at Town Hall

White House Officially Addresses Trump & Vance Feud Rumors After Reports the President Is Prepared to 'Strike' Against the VP's 'Betrayal'

Armstrong also takes a jab at Vice President JD Vance through revised lyrics of ‚ÄúJesus of Suburbia.‚Äù So what‚Äôs the beef between the president and the band?

After Donald Trump was elected into office in November 2016, the band led a chant ¬†‚ÄúNo Trump, no KKK, no fascist USA‚Äù¬†during an appearance at the¬†American Music Awards.

During the first days of the first Trump administration, Billie Joe Armstrong wrote on Instagram about his immigration executive orders that targeted countries with large Muslim populations: ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm in a state of shock. The executive orders Trump is signing feels like a vendetta.. Trump is not only taking out his revenge on the people who protested him, but also the average American that just didn‚Äôt vote for him.‚Äù

He continued, ‚ÄúThese reckless decisions on healthcare, muslim-americans, immigration, environmental protection, freedom of speech, freedom of press, women‚Äôs right to choose what to do with their bodies, suggesting sending in the feds to Chicago .. are signs of a man that is trying to redefine what it is that keeps our common union as Americans. This is not just his ‚Äòconservative agenda.‚Äô¬†It‚Äôs an all out assault on our civil liberties. His intention is to divide us as Americans.¬†Maybe we don‚Äôt agree on all of these issues.. But can‚Äôt we see eye to eye on some?‚Äù

In an interview with NME, Armstrong said that Trump supporters were mostly¬†‚Äúuneducated white working-class people.‚Äù Armstrong¬†added: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the problem right there. There‚Äôs this white nationalism that‚Äôs been brewing under the radar for a long time. But now [Trump‚Äôs] been able to cause people to lash out and blame minorities and it‚Äôs really confusing. I mean, blatant misogyny going on at the same time.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got family members from Oklahoma that are big Trump supporters.
